education.title: Key Concepts in Restaurant Management
education.subtitle: Master the financial fundamentals every restaurant owner should know to maximize their business profitability.

revenue.title: Total Revenue
revenue.description: Revenue represents all sales generated by your restaurant, including food, beverages, additional services, and declared tips. It's the foundation for calculating all other profitability indicators.

cmv.title: Cost of Goods Sold (COGS)
cmv.description: COGS includes only the cost of ingredients and beverages used to prepare sold dishes. An ideal COGS should be between 25-30% of total revenue to maintain a profitable operation.

labor.title: Labor Costs
labor.description: Includes all staff-related expenses: salaries, social benefits, social security, bonuses, and training. Ideally should represent between 25-35% of total revenue.

operating.title: Operating Expenses
operating.description: All expenses necessary to keep the restaurant running, divided into fixed costs (rent, insurance, licenses) and variable costs (marketing, maintenance, supplies). Typically represent 15-25% of revenue.

profitability.title: Profitability Analysis
profitability.description: Profitability is measured through net margin, which should be at least 5-10% for a healthy restaurant. This indicator allows you to evaluate the long-term viability of your food business.

analysis.title: Data-Driven Decision Making
analysis.description: Regular financial analysis allows you to identify improvement opportunities, optimize costs, adjust prices, and make strategic decisions that positively impact your restaurant's profitability.

importance.title: Why is it Crucial to Know These Concepts?
importance.description: 80% of restaurants fail within the first 5 years, mainly due to lack of financial control. Mastering these concepts allows you to make informed decisions, identify problems before they become critical, and build a sustainable and profitable food business long-term.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: We answer the most common questions about restaurant financial analysis

items.question: How often should I use this calculator?
items.answer: We recommend using the calculator monthly to monitor your restaurant's financial health. It's also useful when implementing significant changes to menu, prices, or cost structure to evaluate their impact on profitability.

items.question: What should I do if my COGS is above 30%?
items.answer: High COGS indicates you're spending too much on ingredients. Solutions: negotiate better prices with suppliers, reduce waste, control portions, optimize menu focusing on more profitable dishes, and review inventory to avoid excessive purchases.

items.question: How can I reduce labor costs without affecting quality?
items.answer: Optimize schedules according to demand, train staff for greater efficiency, evaluate if you need all current positions, consider technology to automate repetitive processes, and measure productivity by calculating sales per employee per hour.

items.question: What net profit margin is healthy for a restaurant?
items.answer: A healthy net margin for restaurants is between 5-10%. Margins below 3% indicate problems requiring immediate attention. Margins above 10% are excellent and suggest a very efficient operation.

items.question: Should I include tips in revenue?
items.answer: Yes, you should include officially declared tips in revenue, as they form part of the business's total income. However, undeclared tips or those going directly to staff should not be included in this calculation.

items.question: How does seasonality affect these calculations?
items.answer: Seasonality can significantly impact results. We recommend using data from the most representative month of your normal operation, or calculating an average of several months to get a more accurate view of your profitability.

items.question: What's the difference between fixed and variable costs?
items.answer: Fixed costs don't change according to sales level (rent, insurance, licenses). Variable costs fluctuate with sales (marketing, delivery commissions, some supplies). Understanding this difference is key for financial planning.

items.question: Does this calculator work for all types of restaurants?
items.answer: Yes, the calculator is designed to work with full-service restaurants, cafeterias, bars, food trucks, and catering services. Financial principles are universal, although ideal ranges may vary slightly depending on establishment type.
